bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Edgar Mayer, January 30, 1943

div1.p: Hench writes that he is unable to come to New York since he is very busy at Camp Carson, Colorado. Hench's wife is pregnant with their fourth child.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Edgar Mayer, January 30, 1943
div1.opener:
STATION HOSPITAL
Camp Carson, Colorado
January 30, 1943
Dr. Edgar Mayer
New York City
New York
My dear Dr. Mayer:
div1.p:
I was delighted indeed to receive your telegram which
gave me concrete evidence of your continued interest in my Cuban
Yellow Fever studies. I am of course also delighted that you
have been able to interest others in the little venture of mem-
oralizing properly Camp Lazear. Dr. Fishbein knew a little a-
bout it, but I never told him very much of my Cuban discoveries.
To have the support of the new Finlay Institute will go a long
way toward helping me realize my hopes.

Now as to the possibility of my coming to New York on
February 13 - I am not so sure. There are two reasons why I
believe I will not be able to come then. The first is a personal
reason: my wife arrives February 3, and has planned to stay
with me here about three weeks. Here arrival here has been de-
layed two weeks because of the serious illness of my mother in
Rochester, who has just now been able to leave the hospital.
I don't want to make my wife's visit here too short as we are
going to have our fourth baby in March, and it may be some months
before she can visit me in Colorado again. Not only is there this
personal reason, but another, namely, that we are having a great
increase of patients in the hospital. We are opening new wards
every few days and expect to open four wards in the next two
weeks. Three of our men leave today for detached service until
about the middle of February, and five were ordered away three
weeks ago to take special courses in Washington and elsewhere.
So that we are short handed, so much so that I believe that I
should not request leave for at least three or four weeks. Of
course, if Washington orders me away toward the end of February,
that is a different matter, but I don't believe that they would
do that. Our baby will probably be born about the second or
third week in March. Would that be a convenient time for me to
come East, after I have gone home, welcomed the new arrival, and
spent a few days? I should be interested indeed to hear what
you and Dr. Fishbein feel about this. I have not yet heard from
Dr. Fishbein, but I am taking the liberty of sending him a carbon
of this letter.

I should be greatly honored indeed to be allowed to work
more closely with your Board of Directors. I do believe
that my own aspirations dovetail very closely those of your
institute.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. HENCH
Lieut Colonel, M.C. PSH/ra
